moves.5. Nc3: White threatens to move to the coveted d5 square.
moves.6. Bxf4 cxd4 7. Qxd4: Black's weak queenside poses little threat to an early deployment of the queen. This also opens up white's queenside castle.
moves.7... Nbc6 8. Qa4: The knight will remain pinned to the king for the majority of the game.
moves.10. Rxd8+ Kxd8 11. Nxe4 Nd5: Four little knights, all in a row.
moves.12. g3: White is looking for opportunities to trade in order to widen his lead.
moves.13. gxf4: White has the only remaining center pawn.
moves.13... Be6: Black is looking to hem in White's queen, while developing his own pieces.
moves.14. Bc4: White is looking for more trading opportunities.
moves.15. Qxb5 Rc8 16. Bxe6: White jumps the gun on the bishop trade.
moves.16... fxe6 17. Nfg5: White threatens to fork at the f7 square.
moves.17... e5: In his zeal for controlling the center, Black fails to prevent the f7 fork.
moves.18. Nf7+ Ke8: Possibly not the best square for the Black king, as it re-pins his knight.
moves.19. Nxh8 exf4 20. Re1: White is looking for a discovered check.
moves.21. Nd6+ Kd7 22. Nxc8 Kxc8 23. Qxc6+: You have no chance to survive.
moves.23... Kb8 24. Re8#:
All too easy.

Edit: Thanks to everybody who commented on this game, a good point about that Rd1. In defense of black, this was my father and he was buried in work, which is why he didn't have his strongest game out :)
